item.title: Report E-2023040364
item.description:
Report E-2023040364

Identified by scraper @ 2023-04-20T21:08:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-30
  • City: PIEDMONT
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 30, 2023, one (1) 325-gallon tote containing UN3265 was punctured and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the top of the tote. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted surface. FCE personnel utilized absorbent wipes to collect the released chemical from the top of the tote. The crew then underwent a tote transfer via gravity transfer into a new 325-gallon drum. All UN3265 impacted material was containerized in the empty 325-gallon tote. Both totes were left on site.

item.title: Report E-2023030544
item.description:
Report E-2023030544

Identified by scraper @ 2023-04-20T21:08:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-16
  • City: DUNCAN
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HUB
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 16, 2023, at 1205 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Hub Group personnel in Duncan regarding the release of approximately 100 gallons of Hardener for 2K-Premium-Clear Saphir (Resin solution, n.o.s., UN1866, 3, III) from (2) 300-gallon plastic totes. The release was reportedly due to a forklift puncture. No drains or waterways were reported as affected by the release. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release using absorbents, hand tools, and the proper PPE. The damaged totes were cut up and placed in waste drums along with all other waste debris generated. A total of (10) 55-gallon metal drums and (1) 55-gallon plastic drum of waste were generated from this release. The waste drums were then taken offsite by the contractor for proper disposal.

  • Description: During the PM sort operations at the FedEx Express ramp in West Columbia, SC a fiberboard box was observed to be smoking. Further investigation indicated the box contained a laptop which began to smoke briefly. The smoking stopped and the airport fire department was but the package had stopped smoking by the time they arrived. There were no dangerous goods markings or labels on the packaging, and no Shippers Declaration for Dangerous Goods was offered with the shipment. The involved package was placed inside of a salvage drum and help pending further disposition instructions.

  • City: FLORENCE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 12/31/2022 at 1342 hours EST CSXT personnel in the Florence Yard (Florence, SC) discovered UTLX211155, a loaded tank car of Ethyl Acrylate, Stabilized leaking from top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Sasol was notified. HEPACO, a CSXT response contractor, responded and found the vapor line open and the secondary closure plug less than tool tight. The issue was identified, and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper, Sasol Scott Guidry 337-499-1488. HEPACO closed the vapor line and tightened the secondary closure plug tool tight. The car was released back into transportation without delays.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package came out of the unload door at door 13 and box was wet to touch. Upon inspection, metal pail of propyl acetate was dented multiple times and closures clasps were damaged which caused internal leakage. Leaking package was removed from the unload work area and taken to the hazmat cage to be placed inside of a lined drum. DescribePack: Package failure occurred at the clasps used to keep lid on top of the metal pail. Pail was dented multiple time and clasps were displaced which allowed contents to leak internally. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Once package was inspected, it was removed from the unload area and taken to the hazmat cage. Package was placed in a lined drum and staged in proper hazmat area located in hazmat cage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics - NGV advised a 55 gallon drum of UN2522 (6.1) was damaged and delivered to the customer in which the customer completed clean up and sent the trailer back to the XPO terminal. XPO requested ERTS dispatch a crew to inspect the trailer located in their yard at 201 New Hope Dr., Wellford, SC, and verify the trailer floor was cleaned. Contractors arrived onsite and evaluated the trailer and found a small, impacted area measuring approximately 2' x 1'. The material was evaluated with the PID and registered no reading in the PPB range. Crew used a rag and emulsification to wipe down the area. No waste was generated - contractors recycled the PPE and materials.

item.title: Report I-2022120157
item.description:
Report I-2022120157

Identified by scraper @ 2023-04-20T21:08:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-10-03
  • City: SUMTER
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: IWSC CORP.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Cargo tank manhole cover was not secured or closed for transportation. Loading facility does not allow for driver/carrier to inspect manhole covers while on shipper premises. At aprox. 1800 on 10/02/2022 I(Virgil Hatton) was driving IWS truck#77. As part of my evening duties with Nova, I was at the Sumter Rail yard, and hooked up to tanker#9410. I pulled up to the east gate where the security guard and I inspected the exterior and sides of the tanker. We were not able to inspect the top of the tanker due to lack of fall! Protection equipment After leaving the east gate, I was enroute to the Sumter Giant Resource Recovery (GRR) plant. I approched the stop sign at South Housar Str, made a complete stop, went straight for approx. 1/2 mile and made a right turn onto Brooklny St. After approx. 1/2 mile, I came to another stop sign; made a complete stop and turned right onto Fulton St At approx. 1/8 mile, I turned left onto Industrial Rd. After going another approx. 1/8 mile, as I slowed down to make a complete stop in order to turn left into the GRR plant, I glanced in my driver side mirror and saw a surge of liquid dripping down the side of the tanker. I made the left tum and, watching the driver's side mirror, saw the dome lid on top the tanker open in an upright position. I immediately stopped my truck, got out, climbed up the ladder to the top of the tanker, then I closed and Latched the dome lid. I got back in my truck, proceeded through the security gate and parked my truck at the plant. I immediately notified Nova plant supervisor Jeff and Greg. They started Spill Response at this time. After they told me there was nothing more for me to do at this time, I unhooked Tanker#9410 from my truck. I left the GRR plant, and backtracked my route from GRR plant to the rail yard to look for evidence or a spill. There was none. I called Nova supervisor Jeff to inform him there was no spill. ///End of Statement///

  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 21, 2022, one (1) 330-gallon tote of acetone experienced a faulty valve and released approximately four (4) ounces of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to complete the necessary corrective actions. FCE personnel performed a tote transfer of all virgin product, then utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surface. FCE containerized all acetone-impacted material into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: During switching operations at Hayne Yard, the yard crew noticed product leaking from the top of the car. They set it out to the spill pan track. An ER Contractor responded to investigate and repair the car. They found 3 out of 6 manway swing bolts to be only hand tight. They inspected the manway lid gasket and it was in good condition. No exceptions were found with the fittings on the valve plate. The ER Contractor properly secured the manway to a tool tight condition and resealed the valve cover. Once repaired it was released and moved to destination.

item.title: Report I-2022100034
item.description:
Report I-2022100034

Identified by scraper @ 2023-04-20T21:08:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-19
  • City: FORT MILL
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A specification cargo tank 1,000 gallons or greater containing any hazardous materials that (1) received structural damage to the lading retention system or damage that requires repair to a system int
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TEAM LOGISTICS COMPANY LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Team Logistics driver Kirk Ritchings was making a bulk gasoline delivery to Murphy USA store #6740 on 2371 N Dave Lyle Blvd, Rock Hill, SC. In route to the delivery, on I-77 Southbound at mile marker eighty-three, Kirk engaged in an accident. Kirk was driving in lane #2 from right shoulder of roadway. The contributing vehicle was traveling in lane #1. This vehicle then hit a vehicle that was disabled and damaged from a previous accident in the road causing it to veer directly into lane #2, striking the passenger side steer tire of Team Logistics truck. The force from the impact pulled the Team Logistics semi into the right breakdown lane directly into a parked vehicle on the shoulder of road. Upon impact the tractor jackknifed severing the fifth wheel and dislodged from the trailer, then coming to a rest facing northbound. The trailer rolled 180 degrees and came to a rest halfway on breakdown lane and grass area. No products were released due to the rollover. The trailer did suffer one tear on compartment #1 about twenty long near the belly valve. Note, due to the trailer being upside down on its top vapor rail no products were released from the tear. York County Emergency Management, Team Logistics, Rock Hill Fire Department, Rock Hill Emergency Incident Control, and Tony s Wrecker Services all responded to the accident. After meeting with all parties for a safety briefing, the following plan of action was formulated: Rock Hill Fire Department deployed two units with foam and water at the ready for any emergency issues. Rock Hill Incident would bond and ground the overturned tanker and take an Ohm reading. They would then individually un-bolt each corresponding belly valve for removal of products. Team Logistics would provide the secondary transport vehicle and pump all products out of overturned tanker. Tony s Wrecker service would overturn the trailer and manage all towing. The response was a complete success, no further incidents, and no release of any hazardous materials.

Identified by scraper @ 2023-04-20T21:08:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-17
  • City: Florence
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HIGHWAY TRANSPORT CHEMICAL LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During the initial inspection, HEPACO crew members determined approximately 3 gallons of styrene was released onto Florence Mall' s parking lot. The impacted area was approximately 2 feet In length and 3 feet in width. HEPACO crew members initiated work operations by dispersing absorbents onto the affected area. The absorbents were then swept up leaving a visible stain on the asphalt. After completion of the aforementioned activity, HEPACO crew supervisor, Richard Legette, climbed atop the tanker to inspect the dome lid which was the source of the styrene spill. After inspection, it was determined that the dome lid rubber gasket was missing which resulted in the spill. A replacement gasket was given to Mr. Legette by the driver of the tanker and Installed utilizing a non-sparking rubber mallet. The dome lid was then bolted and secured immediately after installation concluded. THe The generated waste, debris, and PPE was placed into one(1) 55-gallon poly drum. Transportation and disposal of the waste was completed under non-hazardous waste manifest No.: 2243.020099. The team members demobilized and returned to the office where equipment was cleaned, restocked, and prepared for future service.

Upon inspecting the inside of the box I found that the cap was loose and the solution inside of the plastic bag began to leak on to the outer packaging. Then the package was placed in a lined drum and closed until further inspection was needed.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During the PM sort operations at the FedEx Express sort facility in Greer, SC a fiberboard box was observed leaking. Further investigation indicated the box contained six plastic bottles of suspected undeclared dg. The bottle that leaked per the associated SDS is listed as UN1824 Sodium hydroxide solution PG II. There were no dangerous goods markings or labels on the packaging, and no Shippers Declaration for Dangerous Goods was offered with the shipment. Following spill cleanup, the involved package was placed inside of a salvage drum and help pending further disposition instructions.

  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSXT
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 06/21/2022 at 1530 hours EST CSXT personnel in the Florence Yard (Florence, SC) discovered UTLX200592, a loaded tank car of Hydrogen Peroxide, Aqueous Solutions leaking from top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Solvay was notified. HEPACO, a CSXT response contractor, responded and found the rupture disk had ruptured. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper, Solvay (Shawn Gleason 713-828-0251). HEPACO replaced the ruptured disk with a new 4 80 psi disk. The car was released back into transportation.
